segments.text: I see the water flooding the kitchen floor, slowly but surely.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: It makes me feel anxious watching it creep closer to the cabinet.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The woman seems so unaware, so caught up in her chores.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I can feel my heart racing each time the boy stretches for the cookies.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: What if he falls and the dishes break?
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: There’s something so innocent about their cookie heist, yet so wrong.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I can’t help but feel a mix of admiration and fear for their audacity.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The girl waiting for her cookie looks so hopeful; it’s almost cute.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: But it all feels so precarious, like a house of cards.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I wish I could freeze this moment and remind them of the dangers.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: Yet, part of me smiles at their spirited mischief.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: How do children manage to be so carefree in a scene that feels so dangerous?
segments.speaker: PAR
